proto_err.errorCount – Error Counting¶

class proto_err.errorCount.counter(ref, errorList=None, samfile=None, opt=None)[source]¶

Takes a list of errors and does some kmer counting

Methods

countAlignedBases(read)
countErrorKmer([maxKmerLength]) Count all kmers in the list of errors of length kmerLen or below before
countRefKmer([maxKmerLength]) Count all kmers in the reference of length kmerLen or below
getCount([truth, emission, kmer, after]) Gets the count for a given {truth,emmision,kmer}

readDiff(read, ref)
setup(opt) Setup output
countAlignedBases(read)[source]¶
countErrorKmer(maxKmerLength=None)[source]¶

Count all kmers in the list of errors of length kmerLen or below before and after and error.

Parameters:

maxKmerLength : int

This is a type. Maximum kmer length
Returns:

emmissionDic,beforeAfterCount :

dict,dict emmissionDic counts the number of times a transition occurs

e.g. {‘A’:{‘T’:123,’C’:123,...,},’T’:{‘A’:123,...},...}

emmissionDic[trueBase][emmitedBase] = count of trueBase -> emmitedBase transition

beforeAfterCount counts the number of times a kmer appears before or after an error

beforeAfterCount[‘before’][trueBase][emmitedBase][kmer] = count of kmer occurance before trueBase -> emmitedBase transition

beforeAfterCount[‘after’][trueBase][emmitedBase][kmer] = count of kmer occurance after trueBase -> emmitedBase transition

These dictonaries are also stored in the counter object in counter.res[‘errorMode’],counter.res[‘kmerCounts’]

See also

countRefKmer

Examples

>>> from errorCount import counter
>>> errorCounter = counter(ref,samfile)
>>> errorCounter.countErrorKmer(maxKmerLength = 3) 
>>> ## counts all possible kmers of length 1,2,3 before and after an error. 
>>> ({'A': {'C': 113, 'T': 105, 'G': 84}, ...}, {'after':{'A': {'C': {'CTT': 2, 'GCA': 1,...},..}} ,'before:{'A': {'C': {'CTT': 2, 'GCA': 1,...},..}}'})
countRefKmer(maxKmerLength=None)[source]¶

Count all kmers in the reference of length kmerLen or below

i.e. counter.countRefKmer(maxKmerLength = 3) counts all possible kmers of length 1,2,3

returns a dictonary of counts in the form

{‘AAT’:123,’AA’:123,...}

This dictonary is also stored in the counter object in counter.res[‘RefCounts’]

getCount(truth=None, emission=None, kmer='', after=False)[source]¶

Gets the count for a given {truth,emmision,kmer}

kmerFreq(seq, kmer)[source]¶

Calculate the number of times a kmer appears in a sequence seq : SeqRecord Object kmer : kmer string

readDiff(read, ref)[source]¶
setup(opt)[source]¶

Setup output

class proto_err.errorCount.error(true, emission, read, readPos)[source]¶

Information about the errors in a read

Parameters:

true: string :

reference base(s)

emission: string :

read base(s)

read: AlignedRead :

pysam AlignedRead object from which error was derived

readPos: int :

position along read where error occured / length of read sequence

See also

counter

Examples

>>> from pysam import AlignedRead
>>> from import proto_err.errorCount import error
>>> read = AlignedRead()
>>> read.seq="AGCTTAGCTAGCTACCTATATCTTGGTCTTGGCCG"
>>> read.qual = '++))++)+*)******)))+)**+*+++)**)*+)'
>>> error = proto_err.errorCount.error('T','A',read,0)
>>> error.isSnp
True
>>> error.isIndel
False
>>> error.qual
11
>>> error.before(2)
NN 
>>> error.after(2)
GC 
>>> error.qscore(0) ## equivalent to error.qual
11
>>> error.qscore(2)
9

Attributes

true string reference bases
emission string Read bases
read AlignedRead pysam AlignedRead object from which error was derived
readPos int position along read where error occured
readPer float position along read where error occured / length of read sequence
alignedDist int or None number of bases between position of start of alignment and where read was sampled None if sampled position n/a
alignedCorrectly bool or None If the alignedDist is less then the read length True else False None is alignedDist is None

Methods

after(j) Return the following j bases,return N when bases missing
before(j) Return the preceding j bases,return N when bases missing
qscore(i) Return the quality score at a base +i i from the error start position
after(j)[source]¶

Return the following j bases,return N when bases missing

before(j)[source]¶

Return the preceding j bases,return N when bases missing

errorType None[source]¶

The type of read error SNP, Insertion or Deletion

isDeletion None[source]¶

Return whether or not the error is a deletion

isIndel None[source]¶

Return whether or not the error is a INDEL

isInsertion None[source]¶

Return whether or not the error is an insertion

isSnp None[source]¶

Return whether or not the error is a SNP

qscore(i)[source]¶

Return the quality score at a base +i i from the error start position error.qscore(0) is equivalent to error.qual

qual None[source]¶

Return quality score of the base where the error occured

class proto_err.errorCount.errorReader(samfile, ref)[source]¶

Iterable over errors in aligned reads

Parameters:

samfile: string :

path to samfile

ref: string :

reference sequence

See also

error, counter

Examples

>>> from proto_err.errorCount import errorReader
>>> reader = errorReader(opt.samfile,ref)
>>> for error in reader:
>>>     print error
SNP error(T to C)
SNP error(A to T)
Deletion error(CGCA to )
...

>>> print reader.readCounter
{'UnMapped': 454, 'mismatchedAlignments': 617, 'Total': 1225, 'perfectAlignments': 154, 'Mapped': 771}

Attributes

readCounter dict A dictonary of counts of read alignment

Methods

next() Returns the next error in the samfile aligned read
next()[source]¶

Returns the next error in the samfile aligned read
